June Cleaver.

comments.author: Zach Haywood

comments.text:
+trha2222 I seriously don't get why you think I'm being racist. If I was, I 
would have used a slur or something derogatory. But I didn't. if I were a 
racist, I would have come right out and said it. And, if you watch the 
special features on the Airplane! DVD, both the Zucker brothers and Barbara 
Billingsley explain how they formulated the Jive dialogue. They both worked 
together with the actors that spoke the Jive talk, and it was something 
they all agreed on. Certainly, if the actors playing the Jive men thought 
there was anything negative or offensive, they would have said so to the 
Zucker brothers, but they didn't. The Jive guys came up with the dialogue 
themselves, and it was agreed between them and the Zucker brothers that the 
dialogue would be in the movie.
comments.author: Zach Haywood

comments.text:
+Zach Haywood
Of course you do. Hey, you better get going. Your local KKK chapter is 
about to start the weekly meeting.
comments.author: trha2222

comments.text:
I know of plenty of people of other races that speak like that, it's a 
product of environment and nothing to do with your race. If you're implying 
here that only blacks speak like that, then maybe you're the racist.
comments.author: Zach Haywood

comments.text:
+Zach Haywood

comments.text:
You are being waaayy too PC. I was in no way being racist, I don't know how

any slurs, state stereotypes, or any of that.

comments.text:

comments.text:
That was the whole point and everyone knew that when the movie was release. 
It was a different time and folks were not mean or were being stupid about 
it. Everyone thought that this was funny and it was designed by the two 
actors and Beaver's mother to take that chance to play this part. They all 
took it in stride and in decency. THAT was the whole point. It is still a 
classic scene today.
comments.author: M Perry

comments.text:
Many people don't know that the Jive guys wrote their own dialogue. They

comments.author: Angela Pierce

comments.text:
Like I said, people were not taking advantage of one another either nor 
going way off the meter as they are today. People were laughing together 
and not AT anyone and people were way more mature about it. Even Richard 
Pryor and Redd Foxx was even too much and had to be X-rated and on its own 
album. But yes, back then, it was an entirely different kind of place and 
it seems as if it were a different kind of world (almost like outer space). 
And yes, Black, White and every other type never tried to harm people or 
pay black face or to put anyone down and try to throw bricks through 
windows or trying to shoot unarmed people in the back. People across the 
board, DID successfully made an effort to get along and work together, made 
movies together which succeeded, made music together with out segregating 
radio stations as they have today. There is too much going on today that 
the trust is shit to crap and like I said, they  can cork those times up 
because the only time that anyone will ever gladly enjoy this kind of 
comedy together is IF this country will get their racist heads out of their 
ass. That said, people decided not to get along today and so there you have 
it. History the way it was in the 80s. Enjoy it strictly on film because 
this'll not be around anytime soon. Thank America for that because THEY 
screwed this up for everyone.
comments.author: M Perry

comments.author: TheKrensada

comments.text:
My parents took me to see this when I was nine. My feet didn't touch the 
floor and I couldn't understand most of the jokes but I giggled like there

say my sense of humor is quite unique?﻿
comments.author: Whtxombi

comments.text:
- 'S'mofo butter layin' me to da' BONE! Jackin' me up... tight me! (I ate 
something that is making my insides cramp up.)
- Cutty say'e can't HANG! (My buddy here says he can't take this for much 
longer.)
- Jus' hang loose, blood. She gonna catch ya up on da rebound on da med 
side. (Just be patient my friend. She's going to bring something on her way 
back to make you feel better.)
- What it is, big mama? My mama no raise no dummies. I dug her rap! (Ma'am, 
I'm not stupid. I understand what she just said.)
- Cut me some slack, Jack! Chump don' want no help, chump don't GET da 
help! (Give me a break! If you don't want help, I won't help you!)
- Jive-ass dude don't got no brains anyhow! Shiiiiit. (Nevermind. You're 
stupid, anyway. Golly!)﻿

comments.text:
This movie had so many jokes that they would not dare use today for fear of 
upsetting some advocacy group. In addition to this they also joked about:

gays
pedophilia
abortion
adolescents having sex

Those jokes would bring heat down on them today, the studios would not okay 
the script.

The irony is we supposedly live in a more liberal society than 35 years 
ago, yet we are so much more restricted in what can be said, or even joked 
about. We have actually gone backward in freedom in that respect.﻿

comments.text: +Lauren Glenn But you did, so good on you! It's all good! ;-)
comments.author: M Perry

comments.text:
+George Ericksen
I have, actually, and it's nowhere near the best Tarantino film. But where 
this film is making fun of black jive, "Django" was portraying slavery and 
the way people spoke about black people. The two are completely unrelated. 
In this day and age, people can toss out derogatory terms in cinema, but 
only if it's portraying a time, place or culture. A scene like the one 
above could never happen today. People are far too obsessed with being PC 
to let that happen.
comments.author: Guigley

comments.text:
+George Ericksen
Django was a period piece.  Using the n word was integral to portraying the 
Antebellum South accurately in the film.

For the record, I was mocking Lauren and people who whine about "political 
correctness", as if the idea that open racists now get publicly shamed and 
shunned is somehow a bad thing.

I'm all for free speech, but words and actions have consequences.  If one 
wants to go around being openly racist and homophobic, then one should 
expect to be shunned by decent society.
comments.author: keefriff99

comments.text: You've obviously never seen the movie, "Django Unchained"
comments.author: George Ericksen

comments.text:
Um, ok.  I wasn't going in that direction but OK.  Look.... anyone who's 
going to victimize or kill someone based on something that they were born 
into isn't someone I want to deal with personally or at all.   I can't 
change the world, but I can change who I socialize with.  And also click 
the Report/Block link.  :p

comments.text:
Something always happens that causes people to breakaway to separate 
themselves.  You have an African American president and still that's not

comments.author: Lauren Glenn

comments.text: Won't happen. Too much has happened since that time.
comments.author: M Perry

comments.text: You understand that I'm not about to read a novel..... so whatever, you win.
comments.author: Lauren Glenn

comments.text:
+Lauren Glenn NO the thing was that people were very cool in a diverse 
environment and it was fair game on BOTH sides and there was no saying of 
the N word just to insult folks. This country cannot handle this today 
because people are too ignorant and have gone too far, so that's what 
happens when America turns a pleasant environment (like that of the 1980s) 
into a mean spiteful environment (the Millennium). No , we can count on 
NEVER enjoying that kind of camaraderie, and remember, it took 70 years 
just for folks to earn that right to play like that...by 2001, folks 
BACKWARDS in disrespecting others in reality and then it became WAYYYY too 
racist,violent and shitty and so the "right" to play like that was gone. 
You had to be there anyway, it was a better time all the way around. If 
anyone was born after 1985 you will never, ever, ever understand the entire 
atmosphere of the 1980s. People MOSTLY respected one another for who they 
were and that just isn't happening today. Just look at the YOU TUBE 
comments across the board. It did not even have anything to do with 
"political correctness", it simply had to do with treating others the way 
YOU want to be treated. Too many freaks who want to stir up the shit pot 
against others. SO we ALL may as well enjoy it on film (and leave it at 
that) because those days will NOT be back at all. Count on it. The country 
should not have gone out of their way to reverse the way things were. No no 
one can be trusted any more. Can't say as I blame any one, either. The 
climate was a better climate in those days for every one and not so damned 
stupid as it is today. People have taken things way too far now and that's 
that.
comments.author: M Perry

comments.author: merloon

comments.text:
I love this scene, it's a shame that in todays world this would probably be 
considered racist or not very PC to include in a movie but, back then it 
was just felt like a warm hearted little joke, black audiences probably 
even felt like it was a little shout out to them to include them in the 
joke rather than an intended slur on their behalf...We generally bond 
better through humour, granted it's not funny to outright insult someone 
but warmheartedly mocking someones general culture is just deemed racist 
now, I'm Irish, anytime I say that people mock and say either I'm an 
alcoholic or whatever else but, to me that's just a conversation starter, 
not an insult. Wish it was still like that everywhere﻿
comments.author: MJPamuru20

Just read the comments way above and you will see why people will NEVER 
take off remarks as lightly like this ever again. If people were not such 
bastards today, maybe, we could all laugh TOGETHER and not laugh AT one 
another...has nothing to do with "political correctness". It has more to do 
with the immaturity level of this society and how too many people go too 
far to DISRESPECT. This film did not disrespect people, it was agreed upon 
to do it in taste and not to insult others. That is what people today do 
not understand and they will never understand that.

comments.text:
DECADES later, this is still some funny shit!! Its a shame that political 
correctness has killed off making movies like this!

Funny thing about this movie and say Blazing Saddles, they throw out racial 
jokes left right and center, but no race, religion or group is off limits, 
and with Blazing Saddles it makes racism ( against blacks) look so stupid 
and pointless that it is more anti racism than most people give it credit 
for!﻿
